content: How A Shortage of Data Scientists in The US is Holding Back Big Data In the United States, a shortage of data scientists is preventing big data from expanding and developing as quickly as it could. Andrej Kovacevic March 8, 2019 March 8, 2019 55 Shares 3,609 Views Share on Facebook Tweet on Twitter + Shutterstock Licensed Photo The demand for big data is on the rise, but the industry is struggling to keep up with demand and develop the best possible algorithms. One of their biggest challenges is trying to recruit enough scientists to leverage big data to its full effectiveness. One survey showed that 1-in-3 data scientists working in the United States were born overseas. Companies in the United States are spending massive amounts of resources to hire and train these employees to work for them. Unfortunately, that isn’t an adequate solution yet, because there are too many logistical hurdles that bottleneck the process. There is the long visa process that is also be very expensive, depending on the type of visa obtained. Of course, once someone secures a work visa, they may not be able to stay indefinitely. This reduces the appeal of working in the United States as a data scientist. There is also a 45% increase in evidence form requests . This is another costly, timely matter for businesses. A shortage of talent is nothing new for companies, and with big data becoming increasingly important, this shortage continues to persist. Some 40% of companies are struggling to secure data analytic talent . This can limit their ability to innovate in almost every industry from pharmaceuticals to automotive manufacturing. Companies will see a slowdown in innovation in the future if the problem isn’t rectified. How the Lack of Big Data Scientists is Being Solved I have spoken with a number of representatives from some of the largest companies in the country. They have all indicated that a shortage of data professionals is limiting their ability to do their job. READ Intent Data 101: What B2Bs Need To Know About This Information Technology companies have the means to hire immigrants, pay for their visas and bring them to work for them. But what else is being done to solve the issue of data scientist job openings not being filled? Colleges and universities . Colleges and universities are doing their part to keep up with the growing demand for big data solutions . The number of big data science and analytic programs across the country is rising. This has led to more than 100 programs in the field. As more higher-education institutes introduce these programs, we will see an increase in qualified data scientists. Internships . Companies have to introduce, and they have to some extent, internships which allow new talent to learn on-the-job. The goal is to help many of these students transition from a background in general business to the company-culture that they need to find success in the business world. Recruitment . More recruiters are searching out data analysts and they can be found on campuses across the country. They also regularly reach out to people on LinkedIn. I have received a number of inquiries from companies hiring data scientists on an almost weekly basis. The goal is to get students interested in the field, and if there’s a demand, these students may opt to specialize in data science. READ Big Data Should be a Priority in Every College Curriculum Internal training is also taking place, which is training or re-training internal workers to take on the role of a data scientist . Cisco has implemented an internal system that offers an education program in partnership with major universities. The company is willing to offer the program to fill their need for data scientists, and it’s a program that has worked very well for the company. Cisco has also opened their own Visualization Lab, which has been used on a variety of projects and will help boost interest internally for data specialties. Other large companies are following in the footsteps of Cisco, working on internal education programs that will be able to train talent they already have in their ranks to fill the role of data scientists. Solving the Big Data Challenge Must be a Priority in 2019 Big data’s importance is seen in everything from the way we drive cars (or how they’ll be automated to drive for us) to help solve the opioid epidemic. With the massive abundance of data being collected on a daily basis, the world’s companies will need to have more data scientists to make use of this data. Otherwise, the potential that the data provides will be all but lost. big data Data Science data scientist shortage data scientists shortage of data scientists Share on Facebook Tweet on Twitter + Author Andrej Kovacevic Andrej is also a dedicated writer and digital evangelist. He is pursuing an ongoing mission to share the benefits of his years of hard-won expertise with business leaders and marketing professionals everywhere. He is a contributor to a wide range of technology-focused publications, where he may be found discussing everything from neural networks and natural language processing to the latest in smart home IoT devices. If there's a new and exciting technology, there's a good chance Andrej is writing about it somewhere out there. How A Shortage of Data Scientists in The US is Holding Back Big Data

In the United States, a shortage of data scientists is preventing big data from expanding and developing as quickly as it could.

Andrej Kovacevic March 8, 2019 March 8, 2019
55 Shares 3,609 Views
  • Share on Facebook
  • Tweet on Twitter
  • +
Shutterstock Licensed Photo

The demand for big data is on the rise, but the industry is struggling to keep up with demand and develop the best possible algorithms. One of their biggest challenges is trying to recruit enough scientists to leverage big data to its full effectiveness. One survey showed that 1-in-3 data scientists working in the United States were born overseas. Companies in the United States are spending massive amounts of resources to hire and train these employees to work for them.

Unfortunately, that isn’t an adequate solution yet, because there are too many logistical hurdles that bottleneck the process. There is the long visa process that is also be very expensive, depending on the type of visa obtained. Of course, once someone secures a work visa, they may not be able to stay indefinitely. This reduces the appeal of working in the United States as a data scientist.

There is also a 45% increase in evidence form requests. This is another costly, timely matter for businesses.

A shortage of talent is nothing new for companies, and with big data becoming increasingly important, this shortage continues to persist. Some 40% of companies are struggling to secure data analytic talent. This can limit their ability to innovate in almost every industry from pharmaceuticals to automotive manufacturing. Companies will see a slowdown in innovation in the future if the problem isn’t rectified.

How the Lack of Big Data Scientists is Being Solved

I have spoken with a number of representatives from some of the largest companies in the country. They have all indicated that a shortage of data professionals is limiting their ability to do their job.

READ
Intent Data 101: What B2Bs Need To Know About This Information

Technology companies have the means to hire immigrants, pay for their visas and bring them to work for them. But what else is being done to solve the issue of data scientist job openings not being filled?

  • Colleges and universities. Colleges and universities are doing their part to keep up with the growing demand for big data solutions. The number of big data science and analytic programs across the country is rising. This has led to more than 100 programs in the field. As more higher-education institutes introduce these programs, we will see an increase in qualified data scientists.
  • Internships. Companies have to introduce, and they have to some extent, internships which allow new talent to learn on-the-job. The goal is to help many of these students transition from a background in general business to the company-culture that they need to find success in the business world.
  • Recruitment. More recruiters are searching out data analysts and they can be found on campuses across the country. They also regularly reach out to people on LinkedIn. I have received a number of inquiries from companies hiring data scientists on an almost weekly basis. The goal is to get students interested in the field, and if there’s a demand, these students may opt to specialize in data science.
READ
Big Data Should be a Priority in Every College Curriculum

Internal training is also taking place, which is training or re-training internal workers to take on the role of a data scientist.

Cisco has implemented an internal system that offers an education program in partnership with major universities. The company is willing to offer the program to fill their need for data scientists, and it’s a program that has worked very well for the company.

Cisco has also opened their own Visualization Lab, which has been used on a variety of projects and will help boost interest internally for data specialties. Other large companies are following in the footsteps of Cisco, working on internal education programs that will be able to train talent they already have in their ranks to fill the role of data scientists.

Solving the Big Data Challenge Must be a Priority in 2019

Big data’s importance is seen in everything from the way we drive cars (or how they’ll be automated to drive for us) to help solve the opioid epidemic. With the massive abundance of data being collected on a daily basis, the world’s companies will need to have more data scientists to make use of this data.

Otherwise, the potential that the data provides will be all but lost.

big dataData Sciencedata scientist shortagedata scientistsshortage of data scientists
